indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Number of research and development actions launched to diversify programming in line with the newly developed country programme.

baseline.comment: Research and development actionsto be launched in line with the newly developed country programme.

target.comment: 1. Acceptance of the Government to integrate research and development in the medium-term national programming. 2. Self-assessment of the institutional capacities conducted in the National State Statistics Committee (NSSC).

actual.comment: 1.UNDP advocated for nominating a Government institution to partner for joint development of an evidence-based new 5-year government programme. A top level expert economist was engaged and a high-level meeting of Deputy ministers organized to share experiences of other countries’ innovative and forward looking policies. The Government accepted to work with UNDP on the development of its new socio-economic five-year programme including to integrate innovations, research and sustainable development goals. 2.UNDP and UNECE have run a number of workshops in the NSSC and helped produce the first draft of the institutional review on statistics.

target.comment: 1.Two new products developed by UNDP in partnership with the Government that foster innovations and use of research in the medium-term policy making Turkmenistan. 2.National State Statistic Committee endorses the institutional self-assessment report.

actual.comment: 1. Methodology for baseline assessment of the national innovation system has been developed and agreed with the Ministry of Economy and Development and Academy of Science; 2. Assessment of foreign trade statistics to be made for further improvement and providing good quality data for research in the area of export-orientation and import substitution.

iati-activity.title: Addressing Climate Change
iati-activity.description: Project aims to strengthen water management practices at national and local levels in response to climate change induced water scarcity risks to local farming systems in Turkmenistan.

location.name: Bokurdak
location.activity-description: At least 8,000 farmers implement community-based well and watering point management measures, including sand fixation and introduction of drought resistant traditional grain varieties in the Karakum desert region

location.name: Kara-Kala
location.activity-description: At least 4,000 agri-pastoralists of the Nohur mountainous region develop and implement water harvesting and saving techniques (such as slope terracing, small rainwater collection dams, contour and stone bunds, planting pits, tillage, mulching) to improve soil moisture levels

location.name: Sakarchäge
location.activity-description: At least 20,000 farmers in the Sakarchaga area benefit from improved irrigation services through the introduction of canal level, localized management practice.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1 Water code subsidiary laws and regulations that introduce progressive pricing policies and communal management for local water services are in place and operational. 2.1 Number of community based adaptation solutions implemented at the local level upon project closure. 2.2 % of population with improved water management practices resilient to climate change impacts in the targeted regions. 3.1 Number of associations with improved institutional capacity to deliver water services to target communities. 3.2 % of targeted population with more secure access to water services in the face of climate change where communal management systems adopted.

baseline.comment: 1. Government has made progressive steps towards improving water management systems. It invests heavily in the improvement and upgrade of water infrastructure and looks out for more advanced technologies. However, water policies remain outdated as well as poorly enforced due to underdeveloped regulations and subsidiary legislation. Tools and methods are missing to indentify the most cost-effective adaptation options in the water policies. Water pricing is largely inadequate. 2. Some of the coping mechanisms employed by farmers, agri-pastoralists and pastoralists in the main agro-ecological systems are increasingly strained due to mounting water deficits. A combination of innovative and traditional measures hasn’t been tested to improve water capture, optimize water demand and improve water efficient applications. Over 2,000,000 people live in the target regions with the majority engaged in agriculture, mainly in marginal lands and having very limited access to stable water delivery services. 3. The State continues to play a far-reaching and predominant role in the economy and acts as the main provider in ensuring adequate living standards of the population, with subsidies, price controls and the free provision of utilities underpinning the system. This has been possible largely due to revenues from the hydrocarbons sector. However, it poses large budgetary burden and results in unsustainable and ineffective water delivery services to farmer and pastoralists communities. Self-functioning and maintained services with the direct engagement of communities are not practiced. Despite existence of water user and farmer associations their role and capacities are limited to improve the water management and delivery options.

target.comment: 1.1- Socio-economic assessment of climate change on water availability including identification of adaptation measures based on cost-benefit analysis and assessing the effectiveness of adaptation activities conducted and submitted to relevant stakeholders 1.2- Amendments to water legislative acts based on the socio-economic study proposed/submitted to Government 2.1- Adaptation measures in the Nohur project region implemented 2.2- Adaptation measures in the Karakum project region implemented 2.3- Adaptation measures in the Sakarchaga project region implemented 3.1- Water user groups with clear objectives, institutional capacity and management skills and supply of water resources in targeted communities organized 3.2- Consultative meetings, Round tables, Working meetings and trainings with representatives of local authorities for their involvement in the planning of water use and local communities for development of investment projects of communties 3.3- Lessons learned on community-based adaptation options in various agro-climatic conditions of Turkmenistan codified and disseminated (e.g. through UNDP web site, local newspapers, ALM and other networks.)

actual.comment: 1.1-Socio-economic assessment has been updated basing on implementation of adaptation measures that were danoe in previous years 1.2-A package of amendments to water code with proposed water tariff and other economic instruments developed and submitted for adoption by end of 2012 1.2-Update of the water code to ensure explicit recognition of on climate impacts on water resource availability by end of 2013 1.2-At least 2 sets of sub- regulations developed under the Water Code to implement a) progressive and differentiated tariffs, b) support for water delivery services under communal management 2.1-At least 50% of farmers implement community-based well and watering point management measures, including sand fixation. 2.1-At least one water harvesting technique and saving measures implemented in Nohur region to benefit 70% agri-pastoralists 2.1-At least 70% of agri-pastoralists and farmers of the Nohur mountainous region trained, develop and implement water harvesting and saving techniques. 2.2-At least two watering points established for at least 50%. Set of at least three agronomic measures implemented in at least 3 communities 2.3-At least 50% farmers in Sakarchaga area to benefit from improved irrigation services through the introduction of canal level, localized management practice. 3.1- WUAs established/strengthened in local communities in three pilot regions. 3.1-Mandates and institutional functions of local associations strengthened to improve local water services that are more resilient to increasing water stress and benefit at least 40% farmers and pastoralists. 3.1-At least 6 associations have clear mandates, institutional capacities and skills to manage and deliver water services to the target communities by end of 2013 3.2-At least 6 community plans on water adaptation have been designed and budgeted through the government’s social development programmes by end of the project 3.2- At least 4 local water adaptation i

target.comment: 1.1-Approval and discussion of conducted socio-economic assessment of the impact of the climate change on water availability and assessing the effectiveness of adaptation activities conducted: 1.1- Social assessment 1.1- Economic assessment of adaptation measures which are being implemented; 1.1- Cost benefit analysis of adaptation measures and submission to the government authorities 2.1- Number of community based adaptation solutions implemented at the local level upon project closure. 2.2- % of population with improved water management practices resilient to climate change impacts in the targeted regions. 3.1- Number of associations with improved institutional capacity to deliver water services to target communities. 3.2-% of targeted population with more secure access to water services in the face of climate change where communal management systems adopted.

actual.comment: 1.1 - More than 40,000 rural people benefit from adaptation measures implemented in the three pilot areas in Nohur, Karakum and Sakarchaga through a community mobilization approach 1.1 – Social assessment has been conducted ( September 2015) 1.1 – Economic assessment has been conducted (September 2015. 1..1 – Cost benefit analysis has been developed (August 2015), working on submission to the government. 2.1 – 70 adaptation measures has been done during the implementation of the project, 27 of them are in 2015. 2.2 – Nohur – 50%, Karakum – 30% and Sakarchage – 80% of the population benefited by improvement of water management. 3.1 – 4 local associations (Yenish, Konegummez, Water User Group #10 and # 15) were improved. 3.2 – Nohur - 50%, Karakum – 30% and Sakarchaga – 30%.

indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment:
1. Notification rate of new smear positive TB cases / number per year per 100 000 population: baseline for 2008 is 22. 2. Number and percentage of new smear-positive TB patients successfully treated (cured plus completed treatment) among the new smear-positive TB patients registered: baseline for 2008 is 83%.
Baseline source: NTP data based on 2008 smear positive case notifications and WHO estimates (‘Global Tuberculosis Control: Epidemiology, Strategy, Financing’ (WHO Report 2009), adjusted for the population size (the national figures are higher than those used by WHO). Baseline rate includes only civilian sector. Targets are set for civillian and penitentiary sectors.

actual.comment: 1. Result for indicator 1 will be available in Feb 2016. 2. Result for indicator 2 will be available in Feb 2016. 3. Result for indicator 3 will be available in Feb 2016. 4. Result for indicator 4 will be available in 2018 (it is analyzed after 36 months from the treatment start).

iati-activity.title: Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings
iati-activity.description: Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings Sector of Turkmenistan

document-link.title: Annual Work Plan for 2013 (in English and Russian languages)
Annual Work Plan for 2014 in English
Annual Work Plan for 2014 in Russian language
Mid-term Evaluation of Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings Project

iati-activity.title: Residential Energy Efficiency
iati-activity.description: The focus of the project is on promoting energy efficiency (EE) by improving energy management and reducing energy consumption in the residential sector in Turkmenistan. This will lead to a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

location.name: Ashgabat
location.activity-description: Direct beneficiaries are families living in 373 apartments in Ashgabat Other beneficiaries: - population of Turkmenistan - Ministry of Construction - Ministry of Communal Services - State Corporation “Turkmengas” - State Corporation “Oil &Gas Construction” - Ashgabat Municipality - State Building De

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Reduction of direct GHG emissions from residential sector of Turkmenistan as a result of the project over 20 years, tCO2e Natural gas saved annually as a direct result of the project Co-financing leveraged for investments in energy efficient reconstruction of existing buildings and construction of new energy efficient housing stock (i.e. beyond existing building code requirements)

baseline.comment: Limited capacity at present to identify and undertake energy efficiency measures throughout national economy. Lack of legal framework to promote energy efficiency, lack of specific policies and programs to improve energy efficiency, lack of energy performance guidelines for existing buildings, lack of awareness of the potential to save energy,. Architects, engineers and policy-makers have insufficient knowledge and capacities on energy efficiency techniques. Absence of energy auditors.

actual.comment: 1-Letter of Agreement with the Ministry of Construction and Architecture on development of new building codes of Turkmenistan and methodological instructions for the new SNT is signed. Building codes have been revised and submitted for the approval to the Ministry of Justice. 1-Ministry of Construction assigned the State Design Institute “Turkmendovlettaslama” as a leading organization for revision of SNT “Building Thermal Engineering” and SNT “Building Climatology”. The Institute is requested by the Ministry to cooperate with the project. 1-A draft of SNT “Building Thermal Engineering” is prepared. SNT “Building Climatology” is pending approval for use of “Turkmenhydromet” data by its Chairman. 1- A draft of the form “Energy passport” to SNT «Building Thermal Engineering» is developed. 2- The Company “Ak Nyshan” is hired to implement 22 energy audits in 9 cities over all velayats. 2-Pilot buildings for energy audits are selected in 5 velayats. 2-Energy audits in 22 buildings in 9 cities over the country are implemented, reports for each of 5 velayats are delivered. 3-The methodology on implementation of energy audits in residential buildings is finalised. 4.1-Calculations of energy consumption baselines for the 2 selected new pilot residential buildings (148U 54-unit building and 114-unit elite building) are completed and confirmed by IC on EE design. 4.1-Designs of demo 114-unit and 66-elite buildings are completed. 4.1-Design of 114-unit elite building is verified by IC on EE design. 4.1-1.2- Letters of Agreement are signed with the owners (clients) of 114-unit and 66-unit elite buildings. 4.1-Contract with a subcontractor for construction of 114-unite elite building is signed. 4.1-Construction of 148U 54-unit demo building (4-th floor level) and 114-unit elite building (12-th floor level) is nearly completed. 4.2-Ministry of Communal Services signed a Deficiency Act for needs for renovation of 3 demo buildings. EE requirements prepared by the project are include

target.comment: -The SNT «Building Thermal Engineering» and «Building Climatology» revised by the end of 2015. -Energy Passport system developed in accordance with revised building codes. -Manual for SNT «Building Thermal Engineering» developed for first review. -Analysis of energy audits in 22 buildings in cities of Turkmenistan conducted. Summary and recommendations prepared. -Monitoring and assessment of energy consumption in 6 selected buildings after initial auditing of energy consumption in 2012. -Recommendations and methodologies on energy management and energy audits developed and presented to interested agencies. -Monitoring of energy consumption of the U-148 building series and of elite (114-unit) building completed, and of elite (66-unit) building begun by the end of 2015. -Renovation of pilot buildings completed and monitoring begun by the end of 2015. -Guidance developed on energy-efficient construction, renovation, and engineering design of buildings -A section entitled «Energy conservation» developed and implemented in typical educational programmes of existing disciplines. Educational materials for the section «Energy Conservation» developed for students by the end of 2015. -Executive reports on results, conclusions, lessons learned, and policy recommendations are prepared and presented to key governmental and regional decision-makers.

actual.comment: - Building codes SNT “Building Thermal Engineering” and SNT “Building Climatology” have been revised and sent to Ministry of Architecture and Construction for starting approval process. - The form “Energy passport” has been developed and included to SNT «Building Thermal Engineering». - The Terms of References for the guidance manual to SNT “Building thermal Engineering” and Catalogue of Joints to prevent thermal bridges have been designed. - The summary on 22 pilot energy audits in 9 cities of Turkmenistan has been prepared, posted on web and printed. - Data of energy consumption have been collected, analyzed and the report on energy monitoring of Koshi pilot buildings has been prepared. Recommendations on energy management to be established for 5 buildings in Koshi area has been prepared. - 4 four-days trainings on energy audit have been carried out in Mary, Turkmenabad, Turkmenbashi and Ashgabat. More 80 specialists have been trained to do energy audits. The National Conference on possible ways to establish energy management in buildings in Turkmenistan has been conducted in Turkmenbashi. - Construction of the elite pilot building is completed in November and energy consumption in the building has been monitored from December, 2015. - The pilot elite building was built without use of any project funds for energy-efficiency measures, as originally planned. Instead, the additional initial costs for the measures were covered by the Contractor “Dovamat”. This means the value of energy efficiency is being recognized by the construction industry in Turkmenistan. - A main part of the renovation of 3 pilot buildings is completed. Only energy efficient measure of establishing windows with low-emission films is postponed to 2016, because of late delivery of low-emission films from abroad. - The manual to establish energymanagement of buildings in Ashgabat under the agency on heat supply “Ashgabatteplo” has been prepared. - The section “Energy conservation” is developed

result.title: Objective
result.description: The proposed UNDP-GEF project will reduce greenhouse gas emissions by improving energy management and reducing energy consumption in the residential sector in Turkmenistan.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Reduction of direct GHG emissions from residential sector of Turkmenistan as a result of the project over 20 years, tCO2e

target.comment: 202,866 tCO2e by the end of the project

actual.comment:
- Estimated direct heat energy savings of 1,484,334 kWh/yr from new pilot buildings. - Estimated avoided CO2 emissions from new buildings over 20-year lifetime of almost 12,265 tonnes.
- Estimated direct heat energy savings of 2,125,588 kWh/yr from renovated pilot buildings.
- Estimated avoided CO2 emissions from renovated buildings over 20-year lifetime of more than 10,845 tonnes. - Total estimated avoided CO2 emissions from 6 pilot buildings over 20-year lifetime of 23,110 tonnes.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Natural gas saved annually as a direct result of the project

target.comment: 5 133 thousand m3

actual.comment:
- Estimated annual natural gas savings of about 322,788 m3 per year in 3 new pilot buildings, and also about 285,400 m3 per year in 3 pilot retrofits.
- Total estimated natural gas savings of about 608,187 m3 per year in 6 pilot buildings.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Co-financing leveraged for investments in energy efficient reconstruction of existing buildings and construction of new energy efficient housing stock (i.e. beyond existing building code requirements)

actual.comment:
- The co-financing by the Government disbursed so far:
*About US $12,300 disbursed for gas meters for 22 demonstration buildings subject to energy audits and 5 demonstration buildings selected for energy management activities.
*More US $40 million disbursed for almost 270 thousand gas meters for residential buildings in the country.
*US $38 million for construction of one demonstration building - 12-story high-comfort building (114 units) including energy efficient design of the high-comfort building. Construction is completed.
*US $16.1 million for construction of second demonstration building - 12-story high-comfort building (66 units) including energy efficient design of the high-comfort building. Construction is to be completed in October 2015.
*US $3.1 million for construction of one demonstration typical 9-story building (54 apartment units). Construction is completed.
*About US $60,000 in in-kind services of the Turkmen State Building Design Institute for revision of building codes Building Thermal Engineering and Building Climatology
- Additional co-financing committed and disbursed for three demonstration projects for energy efficiency in renovation of existing buildings

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Energy consumption in new buildings is reduced beyond current requirements

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Existence and content of applicable building codes on building energy performance

baseline.comment:
- No code on whole-building energy performance. Existing codes regulate thermal resistance of building elements, but not whole-building consumption per square meter. Resultant whole-building energy consumption levels under code compliance therefore vary from building to building.
- Existing thermal engineering code adopted in 1998 contains two levels of prescriptive thermal envelope requirements, Level 1 and Level 2. Buildings consume 35-70 percent less energy under Level 2 than under Level 1, but Level 2 is implemented in practice only for elite residential buildings, not common building designs for standard housing.

target.comment:
- New building energy efficiency code on whole-building thermal performance and revisions of existing building codes on roofs and roofing, residential buildings, and building climatology developed and implemented.
- New code requires heat energy consumption at or beyond Level 2 for all buildings (5 to 10 percent less than Level 2 for elite residential buildings), with Level 1 compliance no longer applicable.
- Introduction of energy passport system in conjunction with adopted new and revised building codes.

actual.comment:
- Building code “Roofs and Roofing” is approved by Ministry of Justice and ordered by Ministry of Construction and Architecture for immediate use.
- Guidance manuals accompanying building codes “Residential Buildings” and “Roofs and Roofing” are translated into Turkmen and approved by Ministry of Construction and Architecture for the use and printing.
- A draft of building code “Building Thermal Engineering” is developed and reviewed by International Consultant and sent to State Design Institute “Turkmendovlettaslama” for review.
- Training for calculation of climatic parameters needed for building code “Building Climatology” has been provided to specialists of National Committee on Hydrometeorology. Software for the calculation is installed and adjusted in the Committee.
- 80 percent of climatic parameters needed for building code “Building climatology” have been calculated by National Committee on Hydrometeorology.
- Terms of Reference for preparing a guidance manual to accompany building code “Building Thermal Engineering” is developed.
- Terms of Reference for developing a software for filling out the energy passport is prepared.
- Terms of Reference for preparing a catalogue of construction materials to accompany building code “Building Thermal Engineering” have been prepared
- 3 Russia’s standards on energy efficiency are purchased to be included to Turkmenistan’s register of standards. 2 CIS standards on energy efficiency are translated into Turkmen to be included further to Turkmenistan’s register of standards.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Turkmengas and other national agencies understand the potential for savings in its housing stock and have the capacity to identify and undertake investments in energy efficiency there.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
- Number of energy audits
- Number of professionals trained

baseline.comment: No audits, training

target.comment:
- 25 energy audits carried out by project (5 planned for 2013, 10 each for 2014 and 2015.
- At least 30 professionals including Turkmengas staff trained.

actual.comment:
- Methodology to conduct energy audits in buildings is finalised and discussed with local stakeholders. It will be sent for confirmation to relevant ministries once the provision on implementation of energy audits is completed.
- A draft of provisions (official instructions) on implementation of energy audits in residential buildings is developed.
- 22 energy audits are implemented in demo buildings in 9 cities of 5 areas of the country; reports and recommendations are prepared.
- Summary of 22 energy audits for the general public is prepared.
- About 100 local specialists in 5 administrative areas of the country are practically trained for the methodology to implement energy audits.
- Gas meters provided by State Corporation “Turkmengas” are installed in 5 buildings selected as pilots for energy management studies.
- Regular measurement of energy consumption is being conducted in 3 demonstration retrofits and 3 baseline buildings.
- Regular measurement of energy consumption (energy monitoring) is being implemented for two new pilot building (their construction is completed in the end of 2014).
- A draft of structure for energy management system for 5 pilot buildings is prepared. Energy audit of the buildings is completed, Data on regular energy consumption in the buildings is collected and analyzed.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Existence and volume of activity of program, run and funded by Turkmengas and/or other state agencies, on energy efficiency investment in buildings

baseline.comment: No investment program

target.comment: Short- and long-term investment plan for Turkmengas and Ashgabat housing stock developed, with EE design and/or retrofit carried out in at least 25 buildings by the end of the project.

actual.comment:
- Energy savings potential is calculated for existing building stock in key cities of Turkmenistan. Options of measures for energy efficient retrofitting of the stock are prepared. Financial assessment and scenarios of investments for energy efficient renovation of the stock have been prepared.
- A draft of National Plan on rational energy use in residential building sector has been prepared.
- Working group composed of representatives of ministries and state organizations relevant to the National plan is established and a meeting of the group is conducted.
- The assessment of energy-saving potential for existing buildings will also be used as a basis project profiles for the National Plan on Mitigation and INDC (Intended Nationally Determined Contributions on climate change) to be presented at the Conference of Parties to UNFCCC in Paris in November 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Energy-efficient design and technologies are incorporated and visually demonstrated in new and reconstructed residential buildings

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
- Number of pilot buildings designed and built
- Energy consumption of pilot buildings relative to similar new and existing buildings in Turkmenistan

baseline.comment:
- No demonstration buildings yet built
- Baseline energy consumption to be determined by calculation based on assumed standard features, as well as code requirements and statistical data on analogous existing buildings if available

target.comment: New pilot buildings designed and constructed with calculated energy consumption 15 percent less than required by code, and five percent less than prevailing best practice for high-comfort buildings

actual.comment:
- Cost estimation completed for one pilot building (12-story 66-unit), with construction in progress and due for completion by October 2015.
- Energy savings in new pilot building to be completed in October 2015:
*66-unit high-comfort - 10 percent compared to baseline
- Monitoring of energy consumption in 2 new buildings completed in the end of 2014 is in progress. For the 9-story building of the U148 series, energy savings over the first five months (November 2014 – March 2015) were measured at 227,618 kWh (~40 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions) relative to a neighboring building identical except for the absence of energy-efficiency measures, and 65,677 kWh (12 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions) beyond code requirements for new buildings. For the 12-story 114-unit high-comfort buildings, energy savings over the same five-month period were measured at 174,598 kWh beyond code requirements (about 31 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
- Number of pilot buildings designed and renovated
- Energy consumption of pilot buildings relative to similar new and existing buildings in Turkmenistan

baseline.comment:
- No demonstration buildings yet renovated
- Baseline energy consumption to be determined by calculation based on assumed standard features, as well as code requirements and statistical data on analogous existing buildings if available

target.comment: Three designs for reconstruction developed and implemented with at least 44% energy consumption reduction

actual.comment:
- Three buildings selected as pilot retrofits are confirmed and co-financing for retrofitting is secured by the Ministry of Communal Services.
- Bilateral agreement on renovation and Letter of Agreement for retrofitting of three typical demo-buildings signed among UNDP/GEF project and client/Ministry of Communal Services.
- Energy efficient measures of three demo retrofits are completed and reviewed by International consultant on building design.
- Cost estimation completed for three pilot retrofits, with renovation in progress and due for completion by November 2015.
- Expected energy savings in three pilot retrofits:
*54-units 148-U typical 44%
*45-units UZ-500 typical 49%
*40-units 76-U typical 51%

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Replication facilitated via development of skills, prototype designs and policies for energy-efficient buildings.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: - Number of architects, engineers, and students trained with regard to enrgy efficient building design and code compliance

baseline.comment: - No training on EE building design and code compliance

target.comment:
- Training on energy efficient building re/construction, experience from implementing integrated building design delivered to at least 50 architects and/or engineers
- Course materials on energy efficient building design and re/construction developed and delivered to at least 30 students by the end of Q4/2014

actual.comment:
- Practical training on implementation of energy audits in residential buildings are delivered to about 100 local specialists in 5 administrative areas of the country in the period of December 2014 - May 2015.
- Training for calculation of climatic parameters needed for building code “Building Climatology” delivered to 10 specialists of National Committee on Hydrometeorology in February 2015. Software for the calculation is installed and adjusted in the Committee.
- Bilateral agreement on revising typical programs for students and Letter of Agreement for developing and adding a section “Energy Conservation” to the typical program of four specialties in Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute signed among UNDP/GEF project and client/Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute.
- A draft of revised typical programs for students and drafts of training materials for lectures, practical and laboratory studies for the “Energy Conservation” section are prepared.
- Information on building codes being revised and practice of energy audits is delivered to teachers and students at a student conference At the Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute in June 2015.
- Benefits of revising building codes and energy efficient measures implemented in new pilot buildings are presented at conferences within International Construction Exhibitions in Ashgabat in August 2014 and April 2015.
- Meeting of Working Group on development of National Plan on rational use of energy resources is conducted in March 2015.
- Terms of Reference for development of guidance for designers to promote energy-efficient integrated residential building design is prepared.
- Study tour on studying energy management experience is organized to Zagreb, Croatia for 7 representatives of national project partners.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: - Existence and content of executive reports and briefings of decision-makers on project findings, lessons learned and recommendations

baseline.comment: - No formal delivery of information or advocacy to decisionmakers on energy efficient buildings

target.comment: - Executive reports and at least one high-level meeting on project findings, lessons learned and recommendations for policy makers developed and delivered to key governmental and regional policy makers by the end of the Q3/2015

actual.comment: Regular communication on project activities with high-level officials at Concern "Turkmengas", Ministry of Construction and Architecture, Ministry of Communal Services, Municipality of Ashgabat, Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute and leading design agencies.

location.name: Ashgabat
location.activity-description: All ministries using ecosystem resources incl. Agriculture, Water, Energy, Fishery, Oil and Gas, Tourism, Trade, Travel, Transport and others.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: By 2015, national targets have been defined for measuring the integration of biodiversity conservation and sustainable use in the agriculture, extractive industries, forestry, livestock, TTTT, fishery and water sectors and these targets are included in the national planning frameworks of the sectors, where available. By 2015, all the main development sector/areas considers biodiversity conservation and sustainable use in their development decisions

baseline.comment: No targets available in order to measure the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem functionality in the agriculture, forestry, tourism, trade, travel and transport and fishery sectors No targets to measure the integration of biodiversity and sustainable development into the main development frameworks of Turkmenistan

actual.comment: 1-The process of planning of biodiversity has been reviewed and state targets on bio-diversity has been developed on response to global Aichi targets; 2- Economic valuation of ES in Turkmenistan, including in subnational level 3- Final draft of National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan of Turkmenistan under the completion. 4- Clearing-house mechanism developed.

target.comment: - Indicators for BSAP implementation within national economic sectors defined - Sectoral implementation plans are developed - National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan of Turkmenistan developed and submitted for review - Effective Clearing-house mechanism operating - Financing strategy developed - Convention on Bio-diversity reporting obligations met

actual.comment: - Indicators for implementations were partially defined during second national biodiversity forum (01/2015). The rest of indicators is planned to be developed under the Regional UNEP project on NBSAP indicators. - Sectoral implementation plans developed during series of sectoral meetings (October-November 2015). -NBSAP of Turkmenistan developed, reviewed by sectors and final version is prepared for final submission to the government - CHM site is created and submitted to the government for approval (preliminary on http://chm.bushluk.com . It will be published back-to-back with the site of the ministry of nature protection (planned to be published soon) - Preliminary financial strategy is developed for the whole NBSAP document. - Reports are submitted by September 2015 in Russian language (Turkmen is also available for 5th national report on CBD). The 5th national report is also being printed in the amount of 500 copies for distribution among stakeholders and academic circles.

location.name: Ashgabat
location.activity-description: Identify views and aspirations of people of Turkmenistan on the future they want for the post-2015 period and effective ways to implement the post-2015 global development framework including building effective institutions and capacities

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 8 target groups consulted on defining priority areas to be refelcted in the next global development agenda

baseline.comment: No target groups for consultations identified

actual.comment: 1. Findings of the second round of consultations on building institutions and developing capacities with 9 line ministries were summarized in the National Report and integrated into the UN Secretary General's Report to the 69th session of General Assembly. 2. 28 out of 60 MDG indicators were verified and found suitable to report in the national MDG report 3. The State Statistics Committee's awareness on global methodologies of consulting institutional assessments of statistical offices was increased. As a result, the UNECE's Adapted Global Assessment methodology was selected for the self-assessment exercise.

target.comment: 1.Support the State Statistics Committee of Turkmenistan in conducting self-assessment in accordance with the recognized international methodologies order to establish the baseline data for the elaboration of SSC long-term development plans.

actual.comment: 1.The State Committee of Turkmenistan on Statistics (Turkmenstat) has undertaken a self-assessment of its institutional framework and operations in order to identify opportunities for improvement. The assessment was conducted using a modified version of the internationally accepted Adapted Global Assessment methodology supported by Eurostat, ECE and EFTA which has been successfully used in the countries of Eastern Europe, Caucasus and Central Asia. The assessment of Turkmenstat has resulted in a series of recommendations relating to the legal framework under which Turkmenstat operates and practical aspects of its operations. Based on the results of the self-assessment UNDP will continue to support SSC in strengthening of the capacity of the national statistical system in Turkmenistan.

location.name: Ashgabat
location.activity-description: The focus will be on the application of the human rights knowledge acquired by officials and the implementation of recommendations accepted by the Government of Turkmenistan during its 2013 UPR.

indicator.title: Output Indicator

actual.comment:
-National Human Rights Action Plan with specific activities and indicators was finalized and submitted for approval by the Government by the end of 2015. A mission of two international experts on learning best practices in monitoring and evaluation in the field of human rights took place. The capacity of the Working Group of the Inter-ministerial Commission in the development of M&E framework of the National Human Rights Action Plan was strengthened.
-The capacity of the Working Group of the Inter-ministerial Commission on Treaty Bodies and International Humanitarian Law in preparation of Common Core Document and reporting on Convention on Elimination on Racial Discrimination (CERD) was strengthened through technical consultations provided by UNDP international experts.
-Awareness of public and government officials about human rights and in respect of Turkmenistan's obligations increased. Public organizations take part in National Human Rights Action Plan discussion and implementation. Train for Trainers group's capacity increased. Due to lack of funds this goal was not implemented but it is scheduled for 2016.
-In 2015, UNDP provided technical advisory support to the Parliament of Turkmenistan and the National Institute of Democracy in the course of development of National legislation on Ombudsman and establishment of Institute of Ombudsman. The members of the Working Group on development of the Law on Ombudsmen received an original training and familiarized with first hand experiences on the best international practices in the area of Institute of Ombudsman with consultation of former Deputy Ombudsman of Catalonia, Spain. The recommendations were provided to the Working Group. The development of the national legislation is still in process.

location.name: Ashgabat
location.activity-description: Build the capacity of the Mejlis and its deputies to be able to pass high quality laws and to monitor their implementation

indicator.title: Output Indicator

actual.comment:
- International consultant conducted three-day seminar for the newly elected deputies and specialists of Mejlis (Parliament) on “Modern methods of improvement of legislation: International Practices” in September 2014. Fifty MPs and experts learned about the international experience of parliamentary theory, functions and structure of parliaments of EU countries, as well as the international standards applied in the law drafting and lawmaking process. In addtion the offline course "Agora" was distributed among the participants, the course was adapted and translated into Russian. This course was designed by International Parliamentary Union and serves as an introductory to the newly elected MPs, the course describes the basic functions and principles of parliamentary institutions. Inrernational consultant had meetings and consultations with Deputy Chair and heads of committees of Mejlis. He discussed issues related to capacity building of MPs in applying norms of international law in the national legislation. His recommendations will be used by the National Parliament to improve the capacity of newly elected deputies and specialists.
-International consultant conducted three-day seminar for the deputies and specialists of Mejlis on “International experience of drafting legislative acts” in December 2014. More than 40 MPs and experts attanded the seminar and learned about the experience of EU and CIS countries, as well as the international standards used in the process of legislation drafting. International consultant held on a series of meetings with MPs and staff of Parliament to develop a handbook “On lawmaking methodology” and capacity development plan for MPs. Both the handbook and the capacity development plan will be used to strengthen capacity and streamline the procedures of the Parliament.
-The webdesiner prepared a brief description of work сompleted under the previous assignment in 2013 and prepared an overview of 5-7 Russian-speaking websites. Curren

baseline.comment:
9 million GJ/year and approximately 6.9 MtCO2/year from water management, including non-agricultural uses
24 billion m3 per year of water consumption for agriculture 2 million hectares of irrigated land 69 percent of irrigated land is moderately to severely salinized; approximately 200 million hectares are severely salinized Water codex adopted in 2004, but no supporting regulations nor regional/local plans for implementation of IWRM or energy efficiency in the water sector

target.comment: - Conducting Inception Workshop - Inception Report - Development of AWP for 2016 and approval by National Partners - Project registration - Organising a Study Tour for National partners to familiarise with the best practices on sustainable water and land management as well as on renewable energy in water management - Preparation of a detailed topographic map of the Green Polygon pilot project site at the SIWMD land. - Reports on Kaakhka and Green Polygon pilot projects, including baseline assessments, detailed work plans, schedules and targeted actions

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Protocols and internal mechanisms for adaptation vulnerability/resilience indicators and gender-disaggregated data collection, storage, processing and use in decision-making and verification established.

baseline.comment: The baseline for the SCCF intervention is the President of Turkmenistan’s Programme for social and economic development for the period 2012-2016, which is a part of a larger development framework - National Programme for social and economic development until 2030. The Programme allocates over USD 150 million to the Ministry of Agriculture for modernization of (water) reclamation system, increase in crop productivity, improving traditional irrigation methods and introducing of new production technologies. In 2016 the next phase of the Programme (2016-2020) will be launched. In addition, part of the baseline is a UNDP financed initiative on Development of Green Economy Strategy for Turkmenistan (US$ 0.7 million). This initiative is in place to support the Government to develop a strategy to advance a Green Economy. Several policy level consultations, stock taking exercises and assessments are planned under this initiative to inform discussions and decisions on the formulation of an action plan to articulate a Green Economy Strategy. The proposed project will build on this programme to ensure that climate change concerns are fully integrated in the articulation of the Green Economy strategy.

target.comment: Initiation and development of TOR's for international and national consultants for development of Project Document.

actual.comment: TOR for national consultants has been developed. TOR for International Consultant/ Climate Change Adaptation/ GEF Expert has been developed

target.comment: Development, submission and approval of Project Document.

actual.comment: Draft Project Document has been developed and will be submitted in December, 2015.

iati-activity.title: Enhancing social inclusion of PWDs
iati-activity.description: To promote employment opportunities for people with disabilities (PWDs) through mainstreaming an inclusive approach into selected vocational training institutions.

iati-activity.title: Enhancing social inclusion of
iati-activity.description: To promote employment opportunities for people with disabilities (PWDs) through mainstreaming an inclusive approach into selected vocational training institutions.

Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: -Education law ensures access to vocational trainings for PWDs. Depending on availability of funds, DBST organizes professional rehabilitation trainings. There is no data regarding the number of PWDs completed vocational trainings. -Only DBST provides professional trainings adjusted to needs of PWDs. There is no information about vocational trainings programme adjusted to need of PWDs. -PWDs have limited access to information about vocational trainings and job opportunities. Educational institutions and employment departments not aware about needs of PWDs.

target.comment: -An inter-ministerial/agency forum made up of senior staff from vocational training institutions in Turkmenistan established. An inclusive model to facilitate participation of PWDs in vocational courses designed together with a broad framework of how to roll out this model.

actual.comment: National Forum “Inclusive Society. State is guarantor of professional education and further employment of PWDs” was held on November 4, 2015. 15 representatives from different government ministries and public organizations, 2 members of the Deaf and Blind Society of Turkmenistan, 4 UNDP staff took part in the Forum. Forum provided opportunity to initiate a dialogue among key stakeholders regarding issues of provision of vocational trainings for PWDs. During the panel discussion with representatives of the DBST, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Textile industry, Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Healthcare, Ministry of Labor and Social Protection, and the National Institute of Democracy and Human Rights under President of Turkmenistan and other public organizations, participants discussed current situation, existing policy and practice, and negotiated inclusive model of education to facilitate participation of people with disabilities in vocational training courses, as well as support programs of the education and employment of people with disabilities in Turkmenistan. International Consultant introduced best international practices in the field of inclusive education and employment of PWDs.
